*

Physics and Poets

Feb 17, 2011

As Montano looked at the physics test, he had a brief recall of falling out of the plane and into enemy territory. He returned to the test. “What is Arminia the capital of?” Ireland . Montano was so confused, though he was certain this was the correct answer. Wasn’t that what the two Irish people had been talking about in the other room? The next question included a drawing of interlocking squares. “Comment on the angle.” Montano winced in confusion. His leg caught that of the person next to him. The teacher? Bugs. “Let me study with you,” demanded Biron as he stepped onto the wharf in pursuit of Persee Shellee. “Me? Well, you’ve tracked me this far. Fine.” Biron was elated. “But how will I contact you?” “Send me an email. I’m here. I’m there. I’m everywhere and nowhere.” Later, the poets were all seated on a concrete slab in the middle of a park under darkened skies. “So-what do we all want to work on?” asked Shellee. He looked at Biron. “I know you want to work on ‘The Painter Fish’. How about you two?” “We just want to work on our computers.” “HEY!” screamed an objector. “Am I the only who thinks its odd that you even have computers? It’s 1833!” Nobody paid him any heed.
